awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: High-Performance Factorization Tools for Constrained and Hidden Tensor Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Tensors generalize matrices to higher dimensions (called modes) and are designed to model multi-way data. Tensor factorization algorithms analyze such multi-way data to uncover relations between the different modes that can be used to both gain insights and to predict unknown aspects of the underlying system/process. For example, medical diagnosis and treatment records can be modeled via a four-mode tensor whose modes correspond to patients, physicians, diagnosis, and treatments and its factorization can provide insights on the co-occurrence of medical conditions, treatment approaches, any treatment differences based on the physician, and identify potential instances of medical fraud. This project's research is designed to address current limitations of tensor analysis by developing new theory and algorithms and high-performance scalable parallel formulations of the various computational kernels used by these algorithms, and a flexible open source software toolkit that can be used to perform constrained and hidden tensor factorization of very large and sparse multi-way datasets. The success of this project will allow researchers to leverage the power of multi-way ``Big Data'' analysis to solve various problems in diverse application domains such as healthcare, medical imaging, cybersecurity, social and behavioral sciences, and e-commerce. At the same time, the project will provide data science training to the students involved by combining cutting-edge data and signal analytics, data mining, and high-performance computing.

Constrained matrix and tensor factorization techniques are widely used for dimensionality reduction, clustering, and estimation in machine learning, signal processing, and many other walks of science and engineering. Unconstrained matrix and tensor factorization algorithms are relatively mature, but constrained counterparts are lagging in terms of speed, scalability, and flexibility. In many applications (e.g., medical imaging and recommender systems), instead of observing the actual entries of a tensor, we observe a limited number of linear combinations (e.g., partial sums) of these entries and need to identify the tensor's latent factors from these measurements. Being able to directly identify the latent factors from linear measurements, which we refer to as hidden tensor factorization, has important advantages in terms of complexity, memory footprint, and the ability to handle very large data sets. Developing open source high-performance parallel tools for constrained and hidden tensor factorization in both shared- and distributed-memory systems will significantly enhance the ability to analyze very large multi-way data. The research will evolve along two synergistic thrusts. First, it will develop new theory and algorithms for constrained and hidden tensor factorization by (i) building fast first-order (FFO) and fast stochastic first-order (FSFO) constrained tensor decomposition algorithms that strike favorable trade-offs between simplicity, scalability, and speed of convergence, and (ii) tackling important identifiability and algorithmic issues related to hidden tensor factorization. Second, it will undertake a multi-pronged effort towards developing high-performance parallel formulations for the computational kernels used in constrained and unconstrained tensor and hidden tensor factorization and develop a high-performance tensor factorization software toolbox. The release of the high-performance tensor factorization toolbox will enable researchers and practitioners to scale up not only the size of data but also the variety of constraints and types of data they can analyze. The research will involve students that will be trained in data science, combining cutting-edge signal and data analytics, data mining, and high-performance computing.

Intellectual Merit

Our research encompasses a wide array of innovative methods and algorithms in data analysis and prediction, each contributing to significant advancements in various domains. By extending frameworks like Canonical Polyadic Decomposition (CPD) to include monomial factorizations, we established deterministic conditions essential for understanding hidden tensor structures and facilitating efficient algorithms for large-scale problems. Furthermore, our work on tensor completion from regular samples addresses critical gaps in both multidimensional sampling theory and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) acceleration. Turning to high-order probability distributions, our work proved that it is possible to identify a high-order but low-rank joint distribution from very low-order marginals. This is a fundamental contribution to multivariate probability. Moving on to nonlinear system identification, our work offered a principled alternative to neural networks, showcasing the potential of tensor-based approaches in challenging scenarios with limited training. Our work on supervised learning and density estimation was the first to use low-rank tensor models to tackle the curse of dimensionality, providing unique characterizations and enabling accurate learning of data distributions. In tackling real-world challenges such as energy disaggregation, retail sales data reconciliation, and pandemic prediction, our tensor-based methodologies demonstrate effectiveness and promise in diverse applications. Furthermore, our innovations in embedding algorithms for graphs offer enhanced locality and memory efficiency, leading to significant improvements in knowledge graph completion, clustering, and question-answering tasks. Overall, our research stands at the forefront of leveraging advanced tensor methodologies to address complex data analysis problems and drive impactful solutions across multiple domains.

 

Broader Impact

Our research has had significant impact on multiple application domains, notably in medical and hyperspectral imaging, data analysis, epidemiology, and predictive modeling. In the realm of medical imaging, particularly in fMRI and hyperspectral imaging, novel approaches utilizing tensor models have emerged from our work on this project. These approaches have not only enhanced fMRI reconstruction, leading to sharper and faster image acquisition, but they have also addressed challenges in hyperspectral super-resolution, improving spatial and spectral resolution simultaneously. Several other researchers have followed up on our work using coupled tensor and matrix factorization for fusing hyperspectral and multispectral images. In the field of neuroscience, advancements in fMRI data analysis have also been made possible through our work on generalized canonical correlation analysis (gCCA). This method has facilitated the extraction of valuable information from multi-subject task-related fMRI data, enabling researchers to identify common brain activation patterns across different individuals. In this context, gCCA yields robust models capable of isolating task-related components amidst complex individual variations, thereby enhancing the understanding of human brain function and behavior. Moreover, the development of tensor disaggregation algorithms has improved data analysis by reconstructing finer-scale data from multiple coarse views. This innovation has profound implications across various domains, including retail, crime analysis, and weather forecasting, by enabling personalized analysis and prediction from aggregated data sources. In healthcare, the Recursive Prediction (REP) framework we proposed can better predict drug sensitivity over time, offering potential insights into long-term treatment outcomes for various conditions. Collaborative pandemic prediction models, such as the STELAR method that we developed, have demonstrated superior accuracy in forecasting epidemic trends, aiding policymakers in implementing timely and effective mitigation strategies.

In addition, the research has provided many graduate students (including four women) working on this project numerous opportunities to develop a better understanding of key analytical and computational tools, including optimization, complexity theory, estimation theory, factor analysis, and high-performance computing. Most of these students have now graduated and are employed in leading industry research labs and in academia.
